column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0120]FIG. 13 illustrates an embodiment of the invention wherein a walking beam includes a flexible porous mesh that is externally heated with hot air.
#Text=In this embodiment, a walking beam containment box 130 includes an externally heated soft, flexible mesh or fabric 131 suspended between at least two frame members 132 as its contact surface.
#Text=For illustration purposes, only one side of the walking beam conveyor is shown.
#Text=The heated mesh is positioned onto the passing labeled containers via a walking beam conveyor in the horizontal direction.

#Text=The label 136 is first applied to a contact point or region on the container with a standard peel tip dispensing process (not shown) with the leading and trailing edges of the label not tacked down.
#Text=The container 135 with the label adhered thereto is moved into the walking beam station via a conveyor and the walking beam moves inward to enclose the container.
#Text=The heated, flexible mesh 131 is positioned to push the label 136 toward the container while removing air from under the label.
#Text=The mesh 131 is heated to a target temperature with a source of hot air 134 based on the line speed and label material selected.
#Text=The hot air from the hot air source 134 is blown through the pores 133 of the mesh to heat the label on the container 135.
#Text=The mesh may be constructed, for example, from a mesh screen, a non-woven fabric or a thin, porous foam sheeting.

#Text=The simultaneous application of heat and pressure from the heated mesh to the label forces the label to conform to the surface of the container, including the compound curve(s) of the container.
#Text=An optional subsequent heating step may be used to further shrink the label 136.
#Text=The advantages of this method include excellent contact with the container and heat transfer from the heated air to the labeled container.
#Text=This method enables very good recovery of heat and recovery of the shape of the mesh.
#Text=This embodiment may be used on a variety of container shapes and is able to achieve higher temperatures based on the thermal stability of the mesh material.

#Text=[0121]FIGS. 14A and 14B illustrate an embodiment of the invention wherein a walking beam 140 includes one or more containment boxes, each having an expandable membrane 142 as its contact surface to create an expandable bladder 143.
#Text=For illustration purposes, only one side of the walking beam conveyor is shown.
#Text=The heated membrane 143 is positioned onto the passing labeled container 145 via a walking beam mechanism, with the container 145 in a horizontal or vertical position.
#Text=The membrane may be constructed of a conformable, high temperature, non-porous high-release material.
#Text=The bladder 143 is filled with a heated liquid or gas so as to heat the membrane 142.
#Text=The heat from the membrane 142 is transferred to the label 146 on the container 145.
#Text=A label may be applied to one or both sides of the container.
#Text=A label may be applied to one or both sides of the container.

#Text=[0122]In this method, the label 146 is first applied to a center section of the container 145 with a standard peel tip dispensing process (not shown) with leading and trailing edges not tacked down.
#Text=The labeled container 145 is moved into the walking beam station 140 via a conveyor and the walking beam closes in on one or more containers 145.

#Text=Pressure from the heated, expanded bladder 143 is applied to the label 146 on the container 145 at a contact point in the center of the label in an outward direction to the edges of the label, pushing any air under the label from the center of the label to the outer edges of the label.
#Text=The expandable bladder is pre-heated to a target temperature based on the line speed and label material used.
#Text=The heat from the bladder membrane 142 softens the label 146 and shrinks the label.

#Text=The simultaneous application of heat and pressure from the bladder membrane 142 to the label forces the label to conform to the surface of the container, including the compound curve(s) of the container.
#Text=An optional subsequent heating step may be used to further shrink the label.
#Text=The advantages of this method include the application of labels to a wide variety of container shapes without the need for retooling.
#Text=In addition, high speed processing is possible due to the continuous heat recovery of the bladder.

#Text=Another advantage is that the application of heat and pressure in a center outward direction in both the vertical and horizontal direction assures proper label application without generating label defects.
#Text=Furthermore, due to the limited number of moving mechanical components, low maintenance is required.

#Text=[0123]The labeled article of the present invention may be used in a variety of applications, including, but not limited to personal care products, household chemical products, food and beverages, toys, electronics, pharmaceuticals, health care products, industrial products and appliances.
#Text=EXAMPLES
